thread.title: MPs warn Theresa May the hard work begins now as she names the date to trigger Article 50
thread.title_full: MPs warn Theresa May the hard work begins now as she names the date to trigger Article 50

author: Jonathan Walker
title: MPs warn Theresa May the hard work begins now as she names the date to trigger Article 50
text:
MPs warn Theresa May the hard work begins now as she names the date to trigger Article 50 Prime Minister Theresa May triggers Article 50 and begins Brexit talks next week, Downing Street announces Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Theresa May confirms she'll trigger Article 50 on March 29 Share this video   Thank you for subscribing!   
Theresa May will trigger EU withdrawal talks under Article 50 on Wednesday March 29, Downing Street has announced. 
The Prime Minister’s letter officially notifying the European Council of the UK’s intention to quit will set in train a two-year negotiation process expected to lead to Britain leaving the EU by March 29 2019. 
But it seems there will be no early general election - despite intense speculation at Westminster. 
The Prime Minister’s official spokesman told journalists: “There is not going to be one.” 
North East MPs urged the Prime Minister to get the best deal possible for the region. Read More Newcastle welcomes Arab business delegation to forge trade links 
Sedgefield Phil Wilson, a Labour MP who had campaigned to stay in the EU, said the UK needed access to the single market - likely to be one of the major sticking points during talks. 
He said: “Theresa May needs to get the best deal out of the EU as possible, and for me that means impediment-free access to the single market. 
“Leave was on the ballot paper, but the means by which we leave wasn’t. So we need to look very carefully at whatever deal Theresa May comes back with. 
“The real hard work starts now.” Prime Minister Theresa May discusses Brexit with Welsh leaders (Photo: PA) 
Gateshead MP Ian Mearns said: “What I would say to the Prime Minister is, whatever you do, always have it in the back of your mind that the implications for the vast majority of people could be quite grave if you get this wrong. 
“Jobs, employment standards, a secure future are all vital to people. 
“And therefore she has got to do as much as she possibly can to protect the livelihoods of ordinary working people and their families.” 
Blyth Valley Labour MP Ronnie Campbell , who supported Brexit during last year’s referendum, warned that the EU may attempt to offer the UK a bad deal, in response to the UK’s decision to quit. Read More North East offers Chinese businesses great opportunities, North East LEP leader says 
He said: “I don’t think they want to give us a good deal. 
“She’s got to go ahead and do it. We’ll have to see when it comes back - it’s going to be a rotten deal. 
“It will be a bad deal because they don’t want us to leave.” Like us on Facebook
